Expectation1: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation1: An emergency diversion cuts across three sectors at once, requiring rapid multi-sector coordination.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A bar mitzvah ceremony that has been planned for months is scheduled to happen.
Story: The headset pressed tight against my ears as alarms flashed across my radar screen. An emergency diversion—Flight 482—was cutting across three sectors, and I had to coordinate with two other controllers, voices tense and clipped, to clear a path. My hands hovered over the console, heart pounding, every second critical. At the same time, my phone buzzed in my pocket. The bar mitzvah was about to begin. Months of preparation, a family counting on me to guide their son through this rite of passage, to offer words of blessing and tradition. I could almost hear the congregation gathering, the expectant hush. But here, in the tower, dozens of lives depended on my focus, my calm. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—one demanding unwavering attention to the skies, the other calling me to the sanctuary, to community and faith. My chest tightened as I realized I could not be in both places. The clock ticked, and I was suspended between two callings, each urgent, each sacred.
